title: Natural Numbers 1 to 10
code:
for i in range(1, 11):
    print(i, end=' ')
explanation: This series represents the first 10 natural numbers starting from 1.

title: Odd Numbers
code:
for i in range(1, 20, 2):
    print(i, end=' ')
explanation: This series consists of all odd numbers, where each term is 2n - 1.

title: Even Numbers
code:
for i in range(2, 21, 2):
    print(i, end=' ')
explanation: This series contains even numbers, each term being a multiple of 2.

title: Squares
code:
for i in range(1, 11):
    print(i**2, end=' ')
explanation: This series contains squares of natural numbers from 1 to 10.

title: Sine Series
code:
import math
x = math.radians(30)
terms = 5
sine = 0
for i in range(terms):
    sign = (-1)**i
    sine += sign * (x**(2*i + 1)) / math.factorial(2*i + 1)
print(sine)
explanation: This is the Taylor series expansion of sine (sin x). It alternates signs and includes odd powers of x.

title: Cosine Series
code:
import math
x = math.radians(30)
terms = 5
cosine = 0
for i in range(terms):
    sign = (-1)**i
    cosine += sign * (x**(2*i)) / math.factorial(2*i)
print(cosine)
explanation: This is the Taylor series for cosine (cos x), containing only even powers of x and alternating signs.

title: Sine Inverse Series
code:
x = 0.5
terms = 5
asinx = 0
coef = [1, 1/6, 3/40, 5/112, 35/1152]
for i in range(terms):
    asinx += coef[i] * (x**(2*i + 1))
print(asinx)
explanation: This is the power series expansion for sin⁻¹(x) (arcsine). It converges for |x| ≤ 1.

title: Cosine Inverse Series
code:
import math
x = 0.5
terms = 5
acosx = math.pi/2
coef = [1, 1/6, 3/40, 5/112, 35/1152]
for i in range(terms):
    acosx -= coef[i] * (x**(2*i + 1))
print(acosx)
explanation: The cosine inverse series is derived from sin⁻¹(x) using the identity cos⁻¹(x) = π/2 - sin⁻¹(x).

title: Factorial Series
code:
fact = 1
for i in range(1, 11):
    fact *= i
    print(fact, end=' ')
explanation: This series lists factorials of numbers from 1! to 10!. Each term is the product of all positive integers up to n.

title: Prime Numbers
formula: Numbers divisible only by 1 and themselves
explanation: This series contains prime numbers between 1 and 30, found by checking divisibility.

title: Reversed Series of All Above
formula: Reverse of each of the above lists
code:
# Example for natural numbers
nums = list(range(1, 11))
print(nums[::-1])
explanation: This entry contains reversed versions of the previous numerical series. For trigonometric ones, reversal is not meaningful.
